Award.AwardTitle: Harnessing self-control in inmates: Self-control strength theory and the reduction of deviance and recidivism

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research in criminology has identified a lack of self-control or "willpower" as one of the reasons as to why people commit crimes. Individuals are often unable to resist the short-term gratification that many criminal acts promise. Many criminologists assume that much of an individual's capacity to exercise self-control is learned early in childhood. Once established, many criminologists consider an individual's capacity for self-control largely unchangeable during adulthood. Recent research in social psychology, however, has found an individual's capacity for self-control to be much more dynamic and variable. Often, self-control functions like a "muscle": it is a limited resource that can be temporarily exhausted through heavy use, but it is strengthened through repeated use. Social psychologists have demonstrated that individuals' capacity for self-control can be enhanced through a relatively simple training. So-trained individuals are better able to resist aggressive and selfish impulses, and make more socially acceptable decisions. This project applies these insights to the U.S. criminal justice system. Many former prison inmates (40-50%) re-offend or violate their parole, and are returned to prison. This contributes to the U.S. having the largest prison population in the world, which comes at great cost to the U.S. economy as well as federal and state budgets, and many socially disadvantaged communities. If recidivism rates can be reduced with a self-control training program that is simple and cheap, there might be large economic and social benefits.

In this experimental study, soon-to-be released prison inmates (volunteers) are randomly assigned to a self-control training condition or a control condition while still in prison (Phase I). Shortly after their release, half of the former inmates are again randomly assigned to a self-control training whereas the other half are assigned to a control condition (Phase II). This results in a 2 (Pre-release/Phase I: Self-control training vs. control) x 2 (Post-release/Phase II: Self-control training vs. control) factorial design. That is, some volunteers will receive self-control training while still in prison as well as shortly after their release; some volunteers will receive training while still in prison only; some volunteers will receive training only after their release; and some volunteers will receive no training at all. At the beginning and end of each phase, various measures of self-control are assessed including individuals' ability to resist the temptation to cheat (Phase I) and the temptation to respond in a hostile manner to provocation (Phase II). This research design allows insight into how much self-control training is needed and when this training needs to occur in order to yield positive effects. Most importantly, this study examines the long-term consequences of the training by monitoring participants'- behavior following the 2 years after their release. If the self-control training is successful, reduced rates of re-offending, greater success of parole and, possibly, greater life success (e.g., employment, education) on the part of trainees will ensue.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Markus Kemmelmeier and a team of graduate students has completed research on the project “Harnessing self-control in inmates: Self-control strength theory and the reduction of deviance and recidivism.” Background of this project was the observation that rates of recidivism are high in the U.S., meaning once inmates are released from prison, there is a great risk that they will commit an offense and be incarcerated again. Recidivism is highest immediately following inmates’ release because living a successful life on the “outside” requires not only skills and resources; rather, it also requires personal strengths, such self-control. Violations of social rules and crime are often a matter of low control, that is, the ability to resist temptation and to hold oneself to a predefined course of action. However, with correctional institutions exercising full control over inmates, prison environments tend to undermine inmates’ ability to engage in self-control, rather than increase it.

This project focused on the development of the capacity to exercise self-control. We conducted an experimental test of a simple and inexpensive method, with which one’s capacity to exercise self-control might be enhanced. Four to six weeks before being released or paroled from prison, inmate participants were randomly assigned to either a self-control training condition or a control condition. Participants in the self-control training condition engaged in daily exercises which previous research had demonstrated would increase self-control capacity. Participants in the control condition were asked to think about self-control on a daily basis that had been shown to not increase one’s capacity to exercise self-control. Via mail correspondence and in-person visits we ensured that all participants followed instructions over a period of three weeks. Once inmate participants were either released or paroled, we tried to reconnect with them, and assigned them to either a self-control training or a control group again, to conduct essentially another round of the same three-week test. That is, some participants would receive the training twice, while incarcerated and after their release; some would receive it while incarcerated, but not on the outside; some would some would not receive it while still incarcerated, but would receive it following their release or parole; and a fourth group would only ever receive the control condition. This research design allowed us to determine whether the self-control training would be effective in harnessing inmates’ capacity to exercise self-control and when it would be most effective to do so. The idea was to then follow our former inmate participants over a period of two years to determine whether the risk of recidivism would differ across the different groups.

Our research generated important insights, but also ran into insurmountable difficulties. First, we observed that our self-control training was effective while participants were still incarcerated. Following the three-week self-control training and while they were still incarcerated, we presented participants with an opportunity to engage in petty theft in a situation in which they were sure not to be found out (even when we had rigged the situation such that we could determine whether petty theft occurred). Volunteers who had completed the training group were more likely to resist the temptation to steal compared to volunteers who were in a control training. Indeed, the risk of stealing was reduced by more than 50%. This improvement occurred regardless of whether our volunteers were imprisoned for a property crime or not. However, self-report measures of self-control did not vary as a function of the training, nor did they predict as to who would steal and who would not.

Second, following participants after their release from prison presented great difficulty. We only succeeded in connecting with a quarter of our original participants. Only a subset was assigned to the self-control training or the control training, and an even smaller subset was able to come to our lab to be exposed to a situation in which we were able to measure the effects of self-control in resisting aggressive impulses. Our data suggest that self-control training increases one’s ability to resist provocation and inhibit aggressive. However, because of the small sample size, the observed differences are not statistically meaningful. Whether participants had received the self-control training while still incarcerated did not influence their capacity to exercise self-control in the lab.

Third, while tracking them for two years, we lost additional participants but reconnected with others. Still, we were successful in retrieving information about many participants from various public sources, especially if they were incarcerated again. Though a number of established variables did predict the risk of recidivism, whether participants had received our self-control training did not.

Our work affirms the emerging scientific consensus that training one’s capacity for self-control is effective. Yet, our work cautions that training effects are short-lived and easily wiped out by life circumstances. Future research must focus on the self-control sustaining characteristics of social environments.
